captions.text: I'd like you all to close your eyes.
Closed? Okay.
Now, you can't see me right now,

but I'm actually riding a unicycle,
juggling hundreds of balls.
(Laughter)
No, keep your eyes closed, though.
It's really great.

But okay. So close your eyes,
and picture an engineer.
Everyone got a picture in their head?
Nod. Okay.
Open your eyes.
Raise your hand

if you pictured a guy
sitting alone at a computer.

Okay. Maybe kind of nerdy,
pocket protector.

Raise your hand if you pictured
a train driver.
(Laughter)
That's a lot of hands.
Raise your hand
if you pictured a young guy in a hoodie,

maybe looks a little
like Mark Zuckerberg perhaps.

Raise your hand if you pictured someone
who looks like me.
Okay. Not a lot of hands.
Well, if you didn't raise your hand for me,

I would like you to please
get up and leave. (Laughter)
No, just kidding.

If you didn't raise your hand for me,
it's all right. I get it all the time.

Usually when I tell people
I'm an engineer,
they look at me and they say,
"Ha! No, really, what do you do?"
or they look at me and say,

"Oh, whoa, you must be
some kind of genius"
or my favorite is when I told my mother
I wanted to major in engineering,
she said, "Eww, why?"
(Laughter)

The truth is I'm a female engineer,
and I'm a minority.

Only 11 percent of engineers
in the U.S. are women.

So why does this matter?
Why do we care?

So what. Let's just have the men
do all the engineering.

Well, engineers are making
some of the biggest advances
in our society.

They're solving things
like global warming,
making medical breakthroughs,

some of the biggest technologies
that are changing our lives.

These are things that we use every day
as people that make our lives better.
And with half the population being female,
we deserve to have the female perspective.

It will only get better
with the female perspective.

But today engineering
really is a boys' club,
and I don't fit in.
But I'm here today to share my story

about how I discovered a passion
for engineering,
and I'm here to make a bold claim:
I don't fit in, but I believe
that our little girls will.

So this is me when I was a little girl,
age six.
I was a pretty normal kid.
I loved ballet and drawing
and riding bikes.

I grew up in a small town
in Rhode Island, age six.

Coincidentally,
this is around the age
where most girls start

to lose an interest in math
and science, this young.

And it's interesting,
some people think,

"Well, biologically maybe girls just
aren't as good as those subjects

and that's just the way it is,
you can't fight nature."

Well, there was a study
done very recently

across 65 countries
around the world

where they tested boys and girls
on the same science test.

Around the world the girls
out-performed the boys,
but not in the U.S.

What the study suggests
is that it's not a biological thing.
This is a cultural thing.
And this is our culture.
This is what we grew up in as girls.

The toy aisle, the perfect example
of our culture,
where we are taught from a very young age
that we want to become princesses.

I remember when I was a little girl,
adults would pat me on the head --

well, actually I come
from a Jewish family;

so they would grab me by the punim
and say,
"Debbie, you are so smart, good for you."

And I remember as a little girl
being so disappointed,
wishing that they told me I was pretty.

I wanted to be pretty,
I didn't want to be smart.

And by the time my senior year
of high school rolled around,
I was applying to college,
and I asked my math teacher
to write my recommendation letter.

She said, "Okay, Debbie,
what do you plan to major in?
I will write it in the letter."
And I said, "I don't know."
She said, "How about engineering?
I think you would really excel in it."
And I thought, engineering.
I closed my eyes --
and I pictured a train driver.
(Laughter)
I had no idea what engineering was,
and I was way too embarrassed to ask her.
I didn't want to sound stupid.

But I thought, "Ugh, no way,
eww, engineering.

That's for boys.
It's intimidating and boring.

And why would she ever think
that a creative, artistic girl like me
would ever like engineering. No way."

But I went off to Stanford,
which was a big deal.

In my high school they actually
announced it over the loud speaker.
(Laughter)

And when I got to Stanford
my freshman year,
I had no idea what to major in.

And that message
that that math teacher had said,
"Engineering, you should give it a try,"
it stuck in my head.
And so I thought, what the heck,

I'm going to take ME101,
just give it a try

because I couldn't shake that advice
that she had given me.

And I was so worried
that it was going to be my first F.
I was terrified, but I went into the class
and in that class I finally
learned what engineering really was.
And to my surprise,
we weren't fixing train engines.
In that class we got to invent
and design things.

We had assignments like
make a catapult out of a soda bottle

and a piece of string and five paper clips
and a piece of foam core.
It was so cool and so much fun.

And in that class,
I learned that engineering

is really the skill set to build
anything you dream up in your head,
whether it's a website
or a mobile app, to a bridge,
to a highway, anything.
That's what engineers build.
And what an amazing skill set.

How empowering to be able
to build whatever you want.
But the problem was I felt kind of alone.
I was always one of a handful
of girls in my classes,
and I did not fit in.
In fact, only 20 percent
of undergraduate degrees

in engineering and tech and science
are awarded to women
so it's a real problem.
But I stuck with it.
I loved the major, and I wanted to do it.

That is, until I took
an engineering drawing class.
This was about halfway through my major
and I thought engineering and drawing,
this is going to be great.
I love art.
Finally, I'm going to get to draw.

The problem was
in this class you had to draw
in perspective, draw in 3-D

and for some reason I had this
total mental block.

I was really struggling
with the material.

And our final assignment
we had to put our drawings
up on the wall for critique.

And you could tell, all the guys
in the class --

there were about 80 of them
and five of us girls --

the guys had scribbled their drawing
ten minutes before
and slapped it up on the wall.

Meanwhile, I had spent hours
the entire weekend.

I didn't even go to any parties,
working on my drawing.

And when the professors
went around the room

and they got to my drawing,
they took a look at it
and they looked out into the room.

And they said,
"Raise your hand

if you think
Debbie should pass this class."

And I just stood there beet red,
humiliated, looking around.

Some people are kind of
half raising their hands.
I was horrified.

And they're like,
"Come on, raise your hand

if you think
Debbie should pass the class."
The room was silent.
Finally, my good friend piped up
and said, "How dare you?

How dare you humiliate her
in front of this room.

She, obviously,
has put a lot of effort in;

and it's your responsibility to teach her,
not to make fun of her."

Well, I'm glad he said that,
but even still,
the tears were streaming down my face.

And I ran out of the classroom
and I thought,
this isn't for me.
I'm not naturally good at this stuff,
maybe I should just give up engineering.
A lot of girls around this time

in their college career
think the same thing.
But my friend came out,
and he said, "Debbie, don't give up.
You can do it, and I'll help you.
We just have to work hard together.

You'll pick up this stuff.
I know you will.

So him and I used to go
from that moment on to the library.

And sometimes we'll be there
until three, four in the morning studying.
And in that library I saw
all of those guys from my classes,

the guys who I thought just knew it
and it was so easy for them.

They it were there
at the library at three in the morning.
I caught them.
(Laughter)

And I realized that it's not about
being a born genius,
it's about how hard you work.
This stuff takes a lot of work.

But I worked really hard,
and I re-did that drawing
and I earned my degree.

Years later I did some research
into this stuff,

and I actually learned
that I was at a disadvantage.
Like a lot of other girls,
I had underdeveloped spatial skills.

The other interesting thing
that I learned is that kids
who score better on spatial skills tests
grew up playing with construction toys.
Well, I thought isn't this a shame.
Me and my little sister growing up,

our parents never bought us
Legos or erector sets or Lincoln logs.
We all thought that those were boys toys.

I thought, those toys have been
marketed to boys for over a hundred years.

And they get them interested
in math and science.

Meanwhile, all we get are
the dolls and makeup kits
and it's not fair.

So I thought, well,
I'm an engineer now.
I have a degree.
I can make anything I want now.

I'm going to make
an engineering toy for girls,
and I'm going to give them the opportunity

that I didn't have
so that they can discover

a passion for engineering
much earlier than I did.
So I got to work.

I quit my job and I worked
out of my apartment for months,
making a prototype
out of thread spools and wooden dowels,

pieces I could find
from the hardware store.

I wanted to find a way to help girls
develop their spatial skills.
I did all of this research.
I met with little girls,
and I found something really interesting.
I'd buy construction toys
and watch them play with them
to see how they could be improved

and time and time again the girls
would get bored with the toys.

And so I would say,
"Well, what is your favorite toy?"
And they would run upstairs
and they would bring back down a book
and they'd say,
"I love reading. Let's read together."

So I came up with a really simple
"aha" idea:
What if I put those two things together.
Spatial plus verbal,
a construction set plus stories.

And what if those stories
were about a girl engineer character
named Goldie Blocks.
And as she goes on adventures,

she solves problems
by building simple machines.

And so the girls read along,
and they get to build with Goldie
and it would bring in a role model,
and it would bring in the narrative
that they so loved.
I made this prototype,
and I went around the Bay Area
testing it on hundreds of kids;
and it worked.
I had little girls
in tutus building belt drives.
(Laughter)
It was awesome.
And I knew I was on to something.

So I had all of these
ram shackled prototypes
in my apartment;

and I've been working for months
like a hermit, not showering.
And a friend of mine said,

"Debbie, do you want
to take this to the next level?
Do you trust me?"

I said, "Yeah, yeah."
"Do you trust me?"

I'm like, "Okay.
We're not in a movie.
What are you talking about?"
He said: "You need to apply
to this tech accelerator program."

It is the most elite program
in Silicon Valley.
All the top engineers around the world vie
for a position in this program.
You need to apply."
So I applied,
and I got in to the big interview day.

And I walked into a room
of Mark Zuckerburgs
sitting there on their computers.
Meanwhile, me walking in,
the chick with the physical prototype.

And I had a napkin over it because,
obviously,
I had to protect my intellectual property.
(Laughter)
And so I'm walking in there
and gosh, do I not fit in.
And one of the guys pipes up
and says, "Oh, did you bring us cookies?"
(Laughter)
Well, my confidence was pretty shot;
and needless to say,
I didn't get into the accelerator.

They didn't understand
why on earth I would add a book.
So, they didn't get it.
But I didn't give up.

So I brought my prototype
to the New York toy fair.

It's the international biggest
toy show in the U.S.

And I thought, okay, this is it.
I'm going to go.
I'm going to show toy industry veterans.

I'm going to talk to store owners
and see what they have to say
about my engineering toy for girls.

And I walked in there thinking
toy fair is going to be awesome.

There's going to be
all these creative types,
mad scientists, kids running around,
it's going to be so cool.
It was a bunch of old men in suits.
I don't fit in.
Come on. I got through engineering,
and now this?
So I showed people my prototype;

and they all kind of
looked at me with pity.
And they whispered me a well-known
industry secret:
construction toys for girls don't sell.
And they took my by the arm,

and they showed me what does sell,
the pink aisle.
And they said this is the way it is
and so we've come full circle.

And I felt pretty dejected
after that toy fair,
but I wasn't willing to give up.
Just because this is the way things are,
doesn't mean it's how they have to be.
And so I took my prototype.
I partnered with a factory,
and I turned it into a real toy.

The thing was the factory
minimum order was 5,000 toys
and with all of this rejection,

I didn't know
if people were going to want it;
so I put it up on Kickstarter.
I had a goal of raising $150,000
in 30 days to make this toy a reality.
I hit go.
I crossed my fingers,
and I hit my goal in four days.
(Applause)
And our minimum production,
it didn't end up being 5,000 units.
It ended up being over 20,000.

I had stores calling
from all over the world

saying, "My customers are coming in,
they want Goldie Blocks.
What is this Goldie Blocks?"
I had parents calling in saying,

"Yes, my daughter is more
than just a princess."
(Laughter)

I had the press writing articles
all about it.
The world was waiting for this.
They wanted this.
The toy industry had it wrong.
Yeah, sure, some girls like princesses
and tiaras,
and I like that stuff too,
but there's so much more to us than that.
There's so much potential.
And for me,
I couldn't be more happy

to be putting my engineering skills
into this product

because it leverages not only
the math and science
that I worked so hard to learn,
but also leverages my creativity.
And engineering is such a creative thing,
and I never knew it.

And it's so fun for me
to get to use my creative voice

and my artistic skills
as a part of engineering.
And it's so important
that we include that perspective.

And the other thing
that's so great about it
is engineering is for people.
We're designing things for people.
So how fun for me to get
to spend my time playing
and learning with little girls
and understanding what their needs are
and designing things for them.
It couldn't be more rewarding.

Our toys are now hitting
the doorsteps of thousands of girls
around the world.
I just got an email from a mom

who said, "We love playing
Goldie Blocks.

My four and a half year old,
halfway through the game

looked at me and said,
"Mommy, am I an engineer?"

And her mom said, "Yes, sweetie,
you can be.
You can be anything."
For so long, for so many years,
I felt like I didn't fit in
but now I feel like I belong here.

I feel like I belong,
and our little girls do too.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Inspiring the next generation of female engineers: Debbie Sterling at TEDxPSU

comments.text: This vedio makes the girls u to take mechanical engineering.﻿

after your wonderful oration about engineering i got interest in doing

Here, we are missing tinker bell. She is the coolest fairy that made me

house, baskets, unicycle and other small crafts. I am 15 years now and am 
grown up by opening machines and wondering what would make them do their 
work. I feel blessed after watching this video that my family has been very 
supportive. Thank you so much﻿

comments.text: Top top!﻿
comments.author: Elizabeth Mutota

comments.text:
This is for everyone i am an 11 year old female i want to be a mechanic or 
engineer since i made a helicopter in DT i have always been a bit of a 
tomboy since i was young i had poweranger action figures and loved marvel 
and DC and loads of action films when i was about seven a bunch of girls 
pushed me in to a ditch and hit me with sticks i was to scared to fight 
back but to strong to cry i just stood there let them hit me and call me 
transgender until i finally plucked up the courage to fight back i stood 
there then as they were coming towards me i took a risk and dived into the 
thorns they missed me by millimetres so I took the opportunity to run home 
i ran to my bedroom and cried and 4 years later i still have problems with 
it but i just want to give my message that we are all equal no matter race, 
sexuality, size, weight, family, friends or gender we are all perfect and 
all if us are unique and i want you all to realise i am an 11 year old﻿
comments.author: eve lewis

comments.text:
Absolutely awesome!  Though I am not an engineer, I recruit engineers for a 
living.  It's rare and exciting when I can recruit a female engineer. 
Debbie's right.  Changing the trend of getting women to be engineers needs 
to start when they are little girls.﻿
comments.author: Jamie Grenke

comments.text:
I don't care what Gender you are if you've got the talent and the drive you 
can be whatever you want to be. It's just hard work is all that's required. 
We should as a society stop saying Boys need to be this and Girls need to 
be that. When we take a kid to a store we should let them pick what they 
want from the kids isle and embrace their decision. If a Boy wants to be a 
ballet dancer and a Girl wants to be a Software Engineer then that's fine.﻿
comments.author: Omnos Dovah

comments.text:
The sense of "we applaud only on success" that the TED's audiences 
typically have is really disgusting: That said, great talk, it points out a 
variety of important genre issues. ﻿
comments.author: RVStudio

comments.text:
There is only one thing that can stop a woman to become an engineer and 
that is herself. So if you want to be a female engineer GO FOR IT!, don't 
start whining about not being able to fit in the industry. Hell you women 
nowadays have a ton of oportunity even more than males, it must be nice to 
get an scolarship just because of your gender so stop the whining and get 
to it.﻿
comments.author: vizardstorm

comments.text:
i llllllllllllllllllllooooooooooooooovvveeeeeeeeeee math and science and i

comments.author: Norka Carbonell

comments.text:
Mesmerizing....! Bravo! Why no one came up with this earlier! The way we 
think the world is developing so fast yet it still manages to surprise us 
with its absurdity is plain staggering. Although I grew up to be an 
activist after majoring in social studies, I was always the tom-boy girl, I 
always went for LEGOs, driving toy cars of all shapes and sizes, I would 
skate everywhere, I would go to my after school classes for math and 
science and I felt so alone being the only girl in the room...I felt so 
intimidated..... It's so interesting what my parents' reactions were when I 
told them if I wanted to be an architect. "Honey, it's hard for a girl.. 
how about becoming a lawyer?" and my dad is an architect.﻿

comments.text: Thank you very much!﻿

Women not in these fields is not a freaking problem! What about all the 
nasty , dangerous , underpaid jobs millions of men do everyday? Women want

comments.author: chauncy primm

comments.text:
This is amazing, I am a 20 year old girl who had no clue what I wanted to 
do before last summer. I have always been a good student and I love to 
create things. Deciding on a major was difficult for me until I found the 
field of engineering. Although I am intimidated by the next few years in 
order to earn my degree by I am proud to say I am pursuing a degree in 
Chemical Engineering, I would love to design medication one day. It is 
great to watch this video and know that I am not the only one who was 
intimidated but am still going through with it!﻿

comments.author: Brian Herron

comments.text:
This is incredible. I've been a STEM nerd/lover since at least 6th grade. 
My favorite toys were ALWAYS LEGOs. With my younger brother, I made his 
first LEGO for him. My dad's an engineer and even if he didn't have a 
daughter he would be interested in getting more women into STEM careers 
(but he does so he's even more interested). I've designed websites that are 
online and live, and my dad's going to find a website or class or something 
to teach me how to code. My dream school is MIT and I'm only in 8th grade! 
Math (and Science) have always been my favorite subjects and I want to grow 
up to change the world.﻿

you'll make it no doubt! you seem so passionate and hardworking, hopefully

comments.text:
I love this video a lot. So inspiring. I wanna be a computer engineer 
someday but i don't like math and science but I'm not bad at it. In fact my 
grade ranges from 91 and up in both areas. They say i just need practice to 
be really good in it, but  idk.... it scares me not to have the mind of an 
excellent engineer though i really want to be one so badly.﻿
comments.author: Vanessa Astorga

comments.text:
In advance of International Women's Day (Sunday, March 8), we'd like to 
share an inspiring TEDx talk by Debbie Sterling, an engineer and founder of 
GoldieBlox. The toy company was formed to inspire the next generation of 
female engineers. Debbie has made it her mission in life to tackle the 
gender gap in science, technology, engineering and math. #STEM #IWD2015 
#WomensDay﻿
comments.author: ISA

comments.text: Great message.﻿
comments.author: TechGuy Ivan

comments.text:
According to statistical facts, women tend to go for more safe majors such 
as literature, theology, etc.
Males go for more challenging majors
Engineering, CS, etc.
This is not sexism they are FACTS.
And I think it's wonderful more women are going into more challenging 
majors:))﻿
comments.author: Jamie Park

comments.text:
Those people were grown women, it doesn't matter what their parents say any 
more they can do whatever they want to. When are women going to stop using 
society as an excuse to not going into certain majors? If they really want 
to become an engineer, than I'm pretty sure no parent would put a gun to 
their head and drove the to become a psychiatrist.
comments.author: Jamie Park

comments.text:
+Jamie Park
 a lot of their own decisions are socially constructed. I know a family 
where both the sisters went into engineering. Everyone around them was like 
why didnt you do med, its more suited to women. Like everyone. I think 
everyone questioning especially when you're like 16-17 and making career 
decisions can have a big impact.
comments.author: SuperAccounted

comments.text:
And women don't go into challenging career choices because of their own 
decisions. They shouldn't blame society for that.
comments.author: Jamie Park

comments.text:
+Jamie Park
 but the social effect is different.. the toys you play from a young age. 
Also in my experience a lot of men go into engineering because all their 
friends are as well... so it seems to be more off a peer thing.
comments.author: SuperAccounted

comments.text: Men and women have EQUAL opportunities in America
comments.author: Jamie Park

comments.text:
It's not having few opportunities
It's their OWN choice
comments.author: Jamie Park

comments.text:
I noticed that within engineering schools, in the past, women have tended 
to gravitate towards EE, ChemE, BioMedEngr, IE, and not so much ME and 
CivE.  I wonder if this has to do with fewer opportunities as young girls 
to put their hands on tools and machines, and if something like GoldieBlox 
can make a difference and start to change that.  I've certainly worked with 
women ME's who are every bit as talented as their male counterparts.
comments.author: Kevin O'Keefe

comments.text:
Not saying no woman should but it's not going to be common. I mean 
equality obsessed Norway spent billions on engineering programs for years 
and it did nothing to change the 10% women participation in that field. In 
interviews most women summarized engineering in one word "Boring". So here 
we are with all the leeway and encouragement in socialist utopia but most 
women by choice still don't even care.
comments.author: Robert Lenski

comments.text:

comments.author: Mark Bradley

comments.text:
+Mark Bradley you seem like a decent guy thats trying to put things 
together rationally although I can't help but disagree with you big time, 
lol. Of course men can be subjected to injustice but to suggest that men 
have it harder is laughable to me. I think the big mistake you've done is 
use your own experiences and made generalisations about it. But have you 
actually looked at the statistics between men and women? since you're 
talking about assault, do you know what those statistics are between men 
and women? since you're talking about social issues, have you done studies 
in them before and understand privilege and oppression from that angle? or 
do you at least have an interest in them and read about them as oppose to 
letting your own experiences as a man guide to make your opinion to what 
you think is happening. I would really recommend that you actually read 
about these things.

Ps. Feminism isn't actually a bad thing. Believe it or not, without it, it 
also effects men too. Unfortunately its been given a bad name. Your view of 
feminism appears to be very limiting. Try to read into social issues if 
you're making bold statements about it.

comments.text:

comments.author: ASMRMamaZen

comments.text:
I'm sorry to say this but I don't think that she can do very much in order 
to inspire girls to become engineers with her product as it still heavily 
relies on the parents buying them. I believe that the real issue isn't 
getting girls interested in engineering but rather to prevent parents from 
pushing their kids into stereotypical roles because I think that the 
families that buy Miss Sterling's books are the same that would have also 
gotten their girls a variety of toys, including building blocks or Lego. 
She herself states that she only got girly toys as a kid.
We all face society's expectations of gender roles and it is hard to break 
through such set opinions but only if we do so we can really evolve and 
maybe make her vision come true. But as long as the mind sets stay the 
same, girls and boys will still be pushed into "predestined" roles, 
independent of the toys available.﻿

comments.author: Ines Bedmar

comments.text:
WOW!!!!!!!That was so so inspiring and incredible!!! THis speech has just 
saved my day, no, ot only my day, but much more. I have been just soooo 
desperate after a long school day with 2 brutal physics lessons but now I 
have gained the power and motivation for studying physics again!!!! 
Moreover, this video also shows the challenges which women have when they 
study engeneering, but more important how they cope with them. I am 
actually not afraid of the boys although I am the only girl in my physics 
class, On the contrary, I feel very comfortable and I like my physics class 
even more than my English class, which does not even has one male student 
:P Anyway, I am sooooo thankful that I could see this video which gave me 
the power to do my homework :D﻿

comments.author: mindprism

comments.text:
+mindprism You live in a very strange and little educated world. The 
differences exist and have to be respected both sides, only that doesn't 
give anyone the right to descriminate anybody else. I am for equal rights 
but I also am for respect, once again both ways. I don't disrespect anyone 
based on gender or other features. I am a woman engineer and I work at one 
of the biggest IT companies in the world. I am no different from my male 
colleagues. I don't know less. I am not less capable. We are the same. We 
are there for a common goal: make a living, do our best. We all have 
families to feed. Your comments reflect that you know a small amount of 
little serious and decent people, which possibly you are included in. I 
don't agree in hire people just because they are men, women, black or 
white. You must earn it, once again as professional person, not a man, not 
a woman. For you to be able to look at a candidate with all the assest you 
need in your company you should be openminded about who is sitting in front 
of you! You have to look at what that person is capable of, not what the 
person is or isn't gender wise, race wise etc... This, as a woman, is my 
definition of fitting in! Of equality! You couldn't possibly ever perform a 
fair choice because your opinion is clearly biased with immature stupidity.

comments.author: melancholicmusicbox

comments.text:
+Abby C

*Really that is a stereotype okay not all girls are like that.*
But a buttload are, and given that fact it means this drive for equal 
outcomes is pie-in-the-sky bullshit. It will NEVER happen because women are 
what they are.

*You are so rude and jealous that one day a girl might be better than you 
at something!*

Thanks for bringing this to my attention. I forgot to add that women like 
to argue like 8th grade girls.

You don't even have enough logic to understand that how I feel, or my 
manners has no effect on the validity of my argument. Put downs are not an 
argument. This is not "Teen Girl World" this is Adult World.

I would love to see more competent, skilled women - they are hot and a 
pleasure to all. HOWEVER, when you create a system that prioritizes women, 
shields them from criticism, and pushes them in directions they would not 
otherwise go -- you create a class of quasi-competent, insecure, and 
reactionary people who are suffering from affirmative-action-itus. These 
people are a danger to the workforce, a danger to objectivity and fairness.

When this is combined with female narcissism, you have a volatile mix -- 
and you will have pushback from those who get burned by this acid. Then the 
cries will come, "Oh, the misogyny! See how women are treated!"

The motto of feminism should be "Damn the consequences, thats not our 
problem" -- the fuck it isn't, this is YOUR implementation, your solution. 
Doing what superficially seems right is just a bad idea, a defective 
approach. Yet we find feminism traipsing around doing just that, and 
disavowing the consequences.

It has all the trappings of a crusade.

Your post shows that you do not have the mental acumen to deal with this 
topic, you are nothing but a feminist cheerleader.

Rah, rah, rah all you want -- you're just showing the sane among us how 
brain dead your ideology is.
comments.author: mindprism

comments.text:
Really that is a stereotype okay not all girls are like that. You are so

comments.author: Abby C

comments.text:
Then let's get some of the bio girls into chem or phys. That seems to be 
the field filled with peppy starbucks drinking girls. Come on, anybody in 
first year science sees this. and chem and phys deemed the 'harder' science 
courses have very few girls... so let's stop pushing everybody into biomed 
since we know not everybody can be a doctor. It makes me terrified that the 
ones partying all the time are the ones who will go into medicine while 
i'll harmlessly be working on circuits in my future...

maybe a lot of girls aren't cut out for it by personal choice. In my entire 
life, nobody ever said girls couldn't do science or anything else. if we 
wanted to do it, we did it. all my female friends are engineering, math, 
chem, phys, and bio.

I find everybody makes such a big deal out of this, well don't make some 
twitter hashtag about it. actually offer more math courses then. If 99% of 
girls can't find interest in linear algebra, then so what? let people who 
enjoy math/science/engineering do it. who cares if they're girls or boys? 
that doesn't matter. intellectual interest should be the only thing that 
matters.﻿
comments.author: Fate Kyougo

comments.text:
Her little sob story about 7:00 I can relate, the last quarter I had a 
teacher put my paper up on the projector for the whole class to see as an 
example of what not to do. 
I'm a couple years into an engineering degree and I failed a class and had 
to wait all the way till the next school year to begin again because you 
have to take this stuff in sequence. Its really depressing and it makes you 
want to quit. Engineering is very difficult. It doesn't have anything to do 
with being a guy or girl its hard for everyone. ﻿

Cecily.  When I was in the Army, one of the most talented mechanics I had 
the pleasure to work with was a woman.  I remember many times when all you 
could see was the bottom of her boots because the rest of her body was 
wedged  into a heavy truck or bulldozer, just like the male mechanics.  And 
at the end of the day, she'd come back from a field repair job covered in 
mud just like her male counterparts.  If you want it, you CAN do it.

comments.text:
I'm currently studying mechanical engineering and am in my first year here 
at Canada. Only 400 students are accepted into the engineering program and 
I can tell you that less than 20 are girls. I don't let that hold me back 
at all. I am the only black female and yet I am getting 90's in my courses 
through hard work and determination. Don't be held back by people. I had 
the same criticism and still do, being automatically judged as the "weak 
one". But it's funny because now they ask me for help. :)

And I don't get why girls go to the arts. What's worst if you care so much

comments.text:
wish i had this as a kid.. it's okay, i just pretended to be a boy and grew

comments.author: Diana K L

comments.text:
I think the way that 'developing an interest in science' is marketed 
actually almost DROVE ME AWAY from science. No, I didn't grow up with 
building toys, or mini chemistry kits, OR a little engineering kit marketed 
especially for me blah blah blah. This made me feel like I didn't belong in 
science, because I really wouldn't have been interested in these things as 
a kid. No, because I wanted the dolls, and I wanted to run around outside. 
Why do we always have to have some "image" of female scientists and 
engineers? I can't be boxed in like this, and neither can a lot of female 
scientists I know. I'm sorry if I can't express this correctly...but I 
really get the idea that toys like this, while they empower a certain group 
of girls, also brings down and disappoints a whole set of others. Not all 
kids have some innate passion that will just bubble up when they're 6. And 
then there's the kids in college who STILL brag about being interested in 
little chemistry sets when they were 5...that's great, but nobody cares how 
you started, only that you got here. *Rant OVER*﻿
comments.author: izzles369

comments.text:
+Fate Kyougo You will catch up if it's something you really want. I came 
into college feeling really insecure and unsure of what I wanted to do, and 
only ended up declaring my major at the end of sophomore year. I am still 
graduating on time as a senior. It doesn't matter where you started, only 
where you end up, and generally you will get where you want to be with 
enough determination.
comments.author: izzles369

comments.text:
+izzles369 I was caught up in that, loving all the theoretical physics I 
wouldn't see until a master's degree. I just finished one semester of 
university physics and realized it's not for me. and it sucks that I 
realized that so late.

Now I have to catch up a semester of engineering somehow between co-op 
since I plan to switch into mechatronics engineering
comments.author: Fate Kyougo

comments.text:
+Fate Kyougo Yes! I felt bad growing up because I didn't have a passion in 
the way it is marketed. It doesn't help the kids who have that marketed 
passion anyways- they think they're interested in quantum mechanics, but 
can't pass calculus. Then they try so hard to get there, and when they 
realize they don't like what they thought they did, it just destroys them. 
I've seen people like this. Unfortunately, these are the same people who 
made fun of me for not declaring my major until I was sure, for exploring 
different sciences before choosing. So I can't help but feel like this 
particular set of people got what they deserved. It is as they always say- 
the proof of the pudding is in the pudding.
comments.author: izzles369

comments.text:
I agree with this.

It's a annoying to see physics students who want to work on black holes, 
string theory, quarks, etc and only that. we're sending flawed messages of 
what it actually is. It's 3 years of chemistry and kinematics and circuits 
and sound waves, etc, before you even get to see that stuff. and nobody 
realizes how math heavy it actually really is

do math than girls. A girl who says, "I don't want to do it" gets moved 
over to the art desk, a boy who says "I don't want to do it" gets told to 
try harder or gets extra instruction. Teachers are (inadvertently, I'm 
sure!) responsible for a large part of the divide.

comments.text:
+aussiebear22 you have really focused on the negatives here. Yes under 
performers and climbers will do anything to manipulate the system to 
survive or get ahead. 
I have seen both males and females pull the harrassment, bullying, stress 
card. I have also seen chronyism in largely male workforces so it doesnt 
surprise me that it would be found in largely female workforces either.

People are people and I think workforces that have a mix of gender are 
healthier places not worse.
I have worked in the mining industry and the increasing number of women in 
the place has improved the work environment and that is including some of 
the issues you do face due to gender stereotyping from males and females.

Anyway this talk was an excellent talk by an articulate passionate engineer 
who wants to fix a problem and did it. Why not encourage her, I reckon she 
would never pull the harrassment card on you, no need - high performer.

comments.text:

INTERESTED in progression look bad :/

And it's so true, I've had many conversations with my male co-workers. Even 
the gay one was accused of harassment! wtf? Luckily he had a witness and 
said "No she started it."

When my boss interviewed me, he had to delay it for about 10 minutes, 
waiting for a female staff member to sit in and interview. I figured out 
later (the light bulb went off) that he did that to avoid false sexual 
harassment claims. That's ridiculous that he has to go to those measures 
because women are that untrustworthy. I'm ashamed of my gender sometimes, 
because of the blatant BS they pull.

comments.author: Xyluss Nelms

comments.text:
You'll support them until they turn the field of engineering into a place 
of taking offence to everything you do. Just look what happen to that 
scientist over a shirt! They bullied him to tears. Made him cry in public; 
To submit to the Social Justice Warrior thugs.

First they'll start with gender quotas. Then Human Resources (which are 
mostly women), will enforce it and specifically pick more women over male 
candidates of future employees. (Intentionally ignore males in favour of 
women.)

Then they'll turn the place into one social justice warrior zone of taking 
offence to everything you do.

After a couple years, you'll find you are walking egg shells.

You'll eventually hold back in contributions because if you dare make her 
"feel" incompetent, she'll turn to HR. All she has to do is make a claim of 
sexual harassment based on how she "feels". And you'll be entangled in a 
"he says, she says" scenario where you will be punished. (Women support 
women. How do you think you can defend yourself if HR and your accuser are 
in alignment with one another? One is more concerned with pushing more 
women into positions, regardless of cost, and the other knows she can get 
away with making dishonest accusations.)

Punishment will be some form of "sensitivity training". Where you are 
emotionally pressured into admitting you are guilty. (Even if you have done 
nothing)...Little do you know, you are already guilty if you are male. 
Especially a white male.

Over time, you'll end up miserable and frustrated to the point where you 
quit or leave the field altogether. (Which is exactly what ALL Feminists 
want. To drive out all males of any areas where society deems of high 
status.)

...And when regular women enter that area, they will wonder: "Where are all 
the men?"

How do I know all this?

I've seen this implemented in Government depts in Australia. Its very 
notable in the Dept of Public Prosecutions. (Where my sister used to work). 
There are next to no male legal clerks. They have all been driven out. 
Haven't you noticed Feminists say nothing when there are more women than 
men in certain areas, despite claiming they are for "equality"? Its a total 
lie. Their words and actions don't align.

On a side note: You wanna know how to make those female legal clerks 
unproductive? Pull the fire alarm in the next building. The females will 
race over to the window and peek down to oogle over firemen responding to 
the alarm. (My sister noticed this behaviour over some fire drill in the 
next building).


I was an engineer. I resigned because I found out that my former employer 
were put in a position where if they don't have more female engineers, they 
would not get the lucrative Govt contract. This all happened while I was 
sitting on the toilet and overheard two management guys discussing whether 
to promote a woman over me because they needed to fill the quota. They were 
conflicted because I made considerable contributions to the company and led 
a good team in past projects.

24 hours later, I resigned. I want no part in a politically correct society 
who only cares about what is between your legs, the colour of your skin, 
etc than competence, skill, and useful contributions that can be made.

I later learned they won the bid to the contract, but fumbled it so bad 
they lost it to a rival. They were later "acquired" (bought out) by one of 
the bigger companies.


By the way, the only way to defend yourself against a "he said, she said" 
scenario is with a camera or smartphone. Something that records voice or 
video. Because people tend to behave very differently when they see they 
are being recorded.
comments.author: aussiebear22
